item.title: California passes ambitious climate targets | Climate Home - climate change news
item.description:
California passes ambitious climate targets | Climate Home - climate change news

New law requires the US economic powerhouse to cut its emissions by 40% below 1990 levels by 2030 California, the world's sixth largest economy, is set to enter into law one of the most ambitious greenhouse gas reduction regimes in the developed world.

item.title: SLAC, Stanford gadget grabs more solar energy to disinfect water faster
item.description:
SLAC, Stanford gadget grabs more solar energy to disinfect water faster

Menlo Park CA (SPX) Aug 18, 2016 - In many parts of the world, the only way to make germy water safe is by boiling, which consumes precious fuel, or by putting it out in the sun in a plastic bottle so ultraviolet rays will kill the m

item.title: Four ways technology will change how we commute in the future
item.description:
Four ways technology will change how we commute in the future

Columbus, Ohio, is a mid-size city known primarily as the home of Ohio State University, not as a hub of cutting edge technology for public transportation. But that is exactly what this city of 790,000 people plans to be.

item.title: Is blue the new green? Wave power could revolutionize the renewable-energy game
item.description:
Is blue the new green? Wave power could revolutionize the renewable-energy game

Unless you're a surfer, a sailor or the owner of beachfront property during hurricane season, you probably don't spend much time thinking about the power of waves. That may be changing soon. Like a large, slowly building swell miles from shore, the wave-power revolution has quietly and gradually gained momentum.

item.title: Africa droughts prompt calls to start pumping untapped groundwater
item.description:
Africa droughts prompt calls to start pumping untapped groundwater

Despite recent heavy rains, Ethiopia is still reeling from the worst drought to hit the country for half a century, particularly in the livestock-dependent regions of Oromia and Somali. Yet studies (pdf) suggest the country could have billions of cubic metres of untapped groundwater.

item.title: Tiny high-performance solar cells turn power generation sideways
item.description:
Tiny high-performance solar cells turn power generation sideways

Hongrui Jiang inspects the alignment of a light source to illuminate new-generation lateral solar cells. The solar cells developed by Jiang's group harvest almost three times more electricity from incoming light as compared to existing technologies. Image courtesy Stephanie Precourt. For a larger version of this image please go here.

item.title: Paris climate agreement set to become law this year | Climate Home - climate change news
item.description:
Paris climate agreement set to become law this year | Climate Home - climate change news

Fifty-seven countries accounting for 59.88% of global emissions have now indicated they will sign agreement before end of 2016 The Paris climate agreement will become international law by the end of 2016 if countries stick to the promises they have made.

item.title: SolarCity Growth Slows Even More as Musk Details Energy Vision
item.description:
SolarCity Growth Slows Even More as Musk Details Energy Vision

SolarCity Corp. is facing near-term roadblocks as installations slow and the pending acquisition by Tesla Motors Inc. hinders its financing efforts. For billionaire Elon Musk, the long-term picture is more significant, as he rolls out more products and services that will make the biggest U.S. rooftop solar company a key part of his energy strategy.

item.title: Federal Regulators Say Tesla's Bid to Acquire SolarCity Isn't an Antitrust Threat
item.description:
Federal Regulators Say Tesla's Bid to Acquire SolarCity Isn't an Antitrust Threat

NPR: Tesla Clears Antitrust Hurdle in $2.6 Billion Deal for SolarCity Tesla Motors moved a step closer in its bid to buy SolarCity after federal regulators said the $2.6 billion deal doesn't present antitrust concerns.

item.title: Just 90 companies are to blame for most climate change, this 'carbon accountant' says
item.description:
Just 90 companies are to blame for most climate change, this 'carbon accountant' says

Last month, geographer Richard Heede received a subpoena from Representative Lamar Smith (R-TX), chairman of the House of Representatives Committee on Science, Space, and Technology. Smith, a climate change doubter, became concerned when the attorneys general of several states launched investigations into whether ExxonMobil had committed fraud by sowing doubts about climate change even as its own scientists knew it was taking place.
